yes.speechText: This might be scary but it's okay. It means she has a mild airway block.  Let her continue to cough. What else can I help you with?

yes.speechText: Stand firmly or kneel behind her. Put your arms under the armpits and your hands on the lower half of the breastbone. Pull straight back to give chest thrusts. Did the object come out?
yes.secondaryText: Stand firmly or kneel behind her. Put your arms under the armpits and your hands on the lower half of the breastbone. Pull straight back to give chest thrusts. Did the object come out?
yes.title: Choking

no.speechText: Since she doesn't consent to your helping, I suggest calling your local emergency number. Stay with her until advanced help arrives.  What else can I help you with?
no.secondaryText: Stay with her until advanced help arrives.

yes.speechText: Good work! Take a deep breath and when you can, tell her to inform her healthcare provider about this incident.  It's great that you were able to do this. You may want to think about taking an American Heart Association first aid course in case this happens again. You can get more information at heart.org/firstaid. What else can I help you with?
yes.secondaryText: Tell her to inform her healthcare provider about this incident
yes.tertiaryText: You can get more information at heart.org/firstaid
yes.title: Choking

no.speechText: Continue giving thrusts until she can talk, cough or make a sound. If she becomes unresponsive, call your local emergency number and begin CPR. I hope that it doesn't get that far, but if it happens, let me know. I can help you with CPR. What else can I help you with?
no.primaryText: Call your local emergency number and begin CPR
no.secondaryText: Continue giving thrusts until she can talk, cough or make a sound
no.title: Choking

yes.speechText: According to the American Heart Association, you should first call your local emergency number if you see a teen or adult suddenly collapse and is not responsive and not breathing normally. Then, push hard and fast in the center of the chest at the rate of 100 to 120 beats per minute, such as the beat of the classic disco song Stayin Alive... Here is how fast you should push on the chest.

yes.speechText: Stand firmly or kneel behind the person. Wrap your arms around the person's waist so that your fists are in front. Make a fist with one hand. Put the thumb side of your fist slightly above the belly button and well below the breastbone. Grasp the fist with your other hand and give quick upward thrusts into the abdomen. Did the object come out?
yes.secondaryText: Stand firmly or kneel behind the person. Wrap your arms around the person's waist so that your fists are in front. Make a fist with one hand. Put the thumb side of your fist slightly above the belly button and well below the breastbone. Grasp the fist with your other hand and give quick upward thrusts into the abdomen.

yes.speechText: Good work! Take a deep breath and when you can, tell the caregiver to inform the pediatrician about this incident. It's great that you were able to do this. You may want to think about taking an American Heart Association first aid course in case this happens again. You can get more information at heart.org/firstaid. What else can I help you with?

no.speechText: Turn the infant onto his or her back, supporting the head. Give up to 5 chest thrusts, using 2 fingers of your other hand to push on the center of the chest. Repeat, alternating between 5 back slaps and 5 chest thrusts until the infant can breathe, cough, or cry. If the infant becomes unresponsive, make sure the infant is lying on their back on a firm, flat surface, begin CPR and call your local emergency number.  I hope that it doesn't get that far, but if it happens, let me know. I can help you with CPR. I'm going to let you focus now. What else can I help you with?
